Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Situation2: They organize an intensive workshop for community leaders to deeply understand and apply complex theological concepts.
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading the message from the church board: “We need you to lead the workshop this weekend. The leaders are counting on you.” My heart pounded. This was the last weekend before Emily left for her fellowship in London. She’d been dropping hints all week—her favorite movie, the little café we loved, the way she squeezed my hand and said, “I just want us to have some time, just us.” I promised her we’d make memories before she left, but now the church needed me too. They expected me to guide, to teach, to be present for those hungry for understanding. I could picture the eager faces of the community leaders, notebooks open, waiting for me to help them wrestle with faith. But I could also see Emily’s eyes, searching mine for reassurance that she mattered most. The weight of both worlds pressed on my chest, and I felt torn in two, unable to imagine disappointing either.
